condition.description:
The ovaries are part of the female reproductive system. They produce a woman's eggs and female hormones. Each ovary is about the size and shape of an almond.

Cancer of the ovary is not common, but it causes more deaths than other female reproductive cancers. The sooner ovarian cancer is found and treated, the better your chance for recovery. But ovarian cancer is hard to detect early. Women with ovarian cancer may have no symptoms or just mild symptoms until the disease is in an advanced stage. Then it is hard to treat. Symptoms may include

  • A heavy feeling in the pelvis
  • Pain in the lower abdomen
  • Bleeding from the vagina
  • Weight gain or loss
  • Abnormal periods
  • Unexplained back pain that gets worse
  • Gas, nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite

To diagnose ovarian cancer, doctors do one or more tests. They include a physical exam, a pelvic exam, lab tests, ultrasound, or a biopsy. Treatment is usually surgery followed by chemotherapy.

NIH: National Cancer Institute
condition.name: Ovarian cancer

carousel_items: Avastin is a medicine that’s infused into your veins (intravenous infusion) in a clinic or hospital.
You’ll need to be watched in case you have a serious reaction during the first infusion.
Your blood pressure may go up while you're taking Avastin. Check your blood pressure regularly (every 2 to 3 weeks) and talk to your doctor if there are any changes.
You may bleed more easily while you're taking Avastin. Be careful and watch for unusual bleeding or bleeding that doesn't stop easily.
If you're a female, you should avoid getting pregnant while taking Avastin and for at least 6 months after you stop taking it.
Talk to your doctor before getting a vaccine. While you're taking Avastin, the vaccine may not work as well or you might increase your chance of getting sick.

basics.benefits_moa: Avastin is a monoclonal antibody. It binds to an important factor that blocks the blood supply to a tumor and stops the growth of cancer.
basics.bottom_line: Avastin is an effective, first-line option when used together with other medicines for certain types of cancers, but it has to be given in a clinic or hospital and it has many severe side effects.
downsides: Not the best choice if you have heart or kidney problems.
Avastin can damage the ovaries. Talk to your doctor before starting Avastin if you're concerned about getting pregnant.
It may take longer for you to heal. Avastin shouldn't be used for 28 days before and after surgery.
There's no generic available and it can be very expensive.

downsides_processed.orig: Not the best choice if you have heart or kidney problems.
Avastin can damage the ovaries. Talk to your doctor before starting Avastin if you're concerned about getting pregnant.
It may take longer for you to heal. Avastin shouldn't be used for 28 days before and after surgery.
There's no generic available and it can be very expensive.

upsides: In studies, taking Avastin with other chemotherapy (anti-cancer) medicines extended the lives of people with certain types of cancers better than not taking Avastin.
Treats brain, cervical, colorectal, lung, and kidney cancers.
Avastin is used as a first- or second-line choice along with other medicines for certain types of cancers.
Avastin is typically given every 2 to 3 weeks and can be given along with other chemotherapy (anti-cancer) medicines during the same visit.

upsides_processed.orig: In studies, taking Avastin with other chemotherapy (anti-cancer) medicines extended the lives of people with certain types of cancers better than not taking Avastin.
Treats brain, cervical, colorectal, lung, and kidney cancers.
Avastin is used as a first- or second-line choice along with other medicines for certain types of cancers.
Avastin is typically given every 2 to 3 weeks and can be given along with other chemotherapy (anti-cancer) medicines during the same visit.

drugs.name: Avastin

carousel_items_processed.orig: Avastin is a medicine that’s infused into your veins (intravenous infusion) in a clinic or hospital.
You’ll need to be watched in case you have a serious reaction during the first infusion.
Your blood pressure may go up while you're taking Avastin. Check your blood pressure regularly (every 2 to 3 weeks) and talk to your doctor if there are any changes.
You may bleed more easily while you're taking Avastin. Be careful and watch for unusual bleeding or bleeding that doesn't stop easily.
If you're a female, you should avoid getting pregnant while taking Avastin and for at least 6 months after you stop taking it.
Talk to your doctor before getting a vaccine. While you're taking Avastin, the vaccine may not work as well or you might increase your chance of getting sick.

risks_warnings.title: Stomach or intestine damage
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can cause a hole to develop in your stomach or intestine. Talk to your doctor if you experience pain in your abdomen, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or fever.

description_processed.orig: Avastin can cause a hole to develop in your stomach or intestine. Talk to your doctor if you experience pain in your abdomen, nausea, vomiting, constipation, or fever.

risks_warnings.title: Lower wound healing
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can lower your ability to heal from a wound, especially from surgery. Avastin shouldn't be used for 28 days before and after surgery, and until the surgical wound is fully healed.

description_processed.orig: Avastin can lower your ability to heal from a wound, especially from surgery. Avastin shouldn't be used for 28 days before and after surgery, and until the surgical wound is fully healed.

risks_warnings.title: Increased bleeding
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can cause severe or fatal bleeding in the brain, nose, stomach, and vagina, and may also cause coughing up blood. Avastin can increase the risk of bleeding or bruising if you're also taking aspirin, NSAIDs (like ibuprofen), warfarin, or other anticoagulants. Tell your doctor about any bruising that doesn't improve, black stools, pink or red urine, or unusual bleeding (for example, from the nose or gums).

description_processed.orig: Avastin can cause severe or fatal bleeding in the brain, nose, stomach, and vagina, and may also cause coughing up blood. Avastin can increase the risk of bleeding or bruising if you're also taking aspirin, NSAIDs (like ibuprofen), warfarin, or other anticoagulants. Tell your doctor about any bruising that doesn't improve, black stools, pink or red urine, or unusual bleeding (for example, from the nose or gums).

risks_warnings.title: High blood pressure
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can increase your blood pressure. Monitor your blood pressure regularly.

description_processed.orig: Avastin can increase your blood pressure. Monitor your blood pressure regularly.

risks_warnings.title: Heart failure
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can increase your risk for heart failure. Talk to your doctor if you have a history of cardiovascular disease.

description_processed.orig: Avastin can increase your risk for heart failure. Talk to your doctor if you have a history of cardiovascular disease.

risks_warnings.title: Ovary damage
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can cause ovarian failure in premenopausal women. Talk to your doctor before starting Avastin if you're concerned about getting pregnant.

description_processed.orig: Avastin can cause ovarian failure in premenopausal women. Talk to your doctor before starting Avastin if you're concerned about getting pregnant.

risks_warnings.title: Kidney damage
risks_warnings.description: Avastin can cause kidney problems due to too much protein in your urine. Talk to your doctor about getting regular kidney tests while taking Avastin.

description_processed.orig: Avastin can cause kidney problems due to too much protein in your urine. Talk to your doctor about getting regular kidney tests while taking Avastin.

carousel_items: Tamoxifen can raise your risk of getting uterine or endometrial cancer. Talk to your doctor if you have abnormal vaginal bleeding or an irregular menstrual cycle.
Common side effects include hot flashes, vaginal discharge, nausea, and vomiting.
Take Tamoxifen once a day with a full glass of water. It can be taken with or without food.
If you're taking the solution, make sure to keep it at room temperature and protect it from light. Throw it away after 3 months, even if you haven't finished all of it.
Drinking grapefruit juice with Tamoxifen can raise your risk of side effects.

basics.benefits_moa: Tamoxifen is an estrogen receptor antagonist. It stops tumor growth by blocking the effects of estrogen in breast tissue.
basics.bottom_line: Tamoxifen is an effective, first-line option for certain types of breast cancers, but it has many severe side effects and needs a lot of monitoring.
downsides: If you're taking Tamoxifen to lower your risk for breast cancer, it can raise your risk of having a stroke or getting a blood clot, especially if you have a history of blood clots or you're currently taking a blood thinner, like warfarin. Tell your doctor about any health conditions before you start taking Tamoxifen.
Can raise the risk of fractures in premenopausal women.
There are many drug interactions, including antidepressants and other chemotherapy (anti-cancer) medicines. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist before making any changes.
Requires regular blood tests and doctor exams to monitor for side effects.
Not the best choice if you have eye or liver problems.

downsides_processed.orig: If you're taking Tamoxifen to lower your risk for breast cancer, it can raise your risk of having a stroke or getting a blood clot, especially if you have a history of blood clots or you're currently taking a blood thinner, like warfarin. Tell your doctor about any health conditions before you start taking Tamoxifen.
Can raise the risk of fractures in premenopausal women.
There are many drug interactions, including antidepressants and other chemotherapy (anti-cancer) medicines. Talk to your doctor or pharmacist before making any changes.
Requires regular blood tests and doctor exams to monitor for side effects.
Not the best choice if you have eye or liver problems.

upsides: In studies, postmenopausal women who were at high risk for breast cancer took Tamoxifen for 5 years and lowered their risk by about 50%.
Tamoxifen is the only medicine approved to lower risk of breast cancer regardless of menopausal status. Other medicines are approved only for postmenopausal women.
Effective in treating metastatic breast cancer in men and women.
Available in both tablets and a sugar-free solution.

upsides_processed.orig: In studies, postmenopausal women who were at high risk for breast cancer took Tamoxifen for 5 years and lowered their risk by about 50%.
Tamoxifen is the only medicine approved to lower risk of breast cancer regardless of menopausal status. Other medicines are approved only for postmenopausal women.
Effective in treating metastatic breast cancer in men and women.
Available in both tablets and a sugar-free solution.

drugs.one_liner: Lowers risk of and treats breast cancer.
drugs.name: Nolvadex

carousel_items_processed.orig: Tamoxifen can raise your risk of getting uterine or endometrial cancer. Talk to your doctor if you have abnormal vaginal bleeding or an irregular menstrual cycle.
Common side effects include hot flashes, vaginal discharge, nausea, and vomiting.
Take Tamoxifen once a day with a full glass of water. It can be taken with or without food.
If you're taking the solution, make sure to keep it at room temperature and protect it from light. Throw it away after 3 months, even if you haven't finished all of it.
Drinking grapefruit juice with Tamoxifen can raise your risk of side effects.

risks_warnings.title: Serious and life-threatening events
risks_warnings.description: If you're at high risk for breast cancer or are a women with Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS), taking Tamoxifen has been associated with uterine cancer, stroke, and blood clots of the lung. Talk to your doctor about the risks before taking Tamoxifen.

description_processed.orig: If you're at high risk for breast cancer or are a women with Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS), taking Tamoxifen has been associated with uterine cancer, stroke, and blood clots of the lung. Talk to your doctor about the risks before taking Tamoxifen.

risks_warnings.title: Harm to fetus
risks_warnings.description: Tamoxifen may cause birth defects or death to a fetus. Don't use Tamoxifen while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

description_processed.orig: Tamoxifen may cause birth defects or death to a fetus. Don't use Tamoxifen while pregnant. If you're considering having a baby, talk to your doctor about alternative medications.

risks_warnings.title: Increased risk of vision changes
risks_warnings.description: Tamoxifen can cause vision changes, such as color perception and cataracts. Talk to your doctor about getting regular eye exams.

description_processed.orig: Tamoxifen can cause vision changes, such as color perception and cataracts. Talk to your doctor about getting regular eye exams.

risks_warnings.title: Worsening liver function
risks_warnings.description: Tamoxifen is processed by the liver. If you have liver problems, talk to your doctor because you may need a different dose. (No dose adjustments are specified on the manufacturer's label.)

description_processed.orig: Tamoxifen is processed by the liver. If you have liver problems, talk to your doctor because you may need a different dose. (No dose adjustments are specified on the manufacturer's label.)

risks_warnings.title: Blood disorders
risks_warnings.description: Rarely, Tamoxifen can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away.

description_processed.orig: Rarely, Tamoxifen can lower white blood cell counts. White blood cells help your body fight infections. Tell your doctor if you have any infection symptoms (such as fever, sore throat, or mouth/throat swelling) that don't go away.
